subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Abjads
msgSnippet:
I ve been listening in for a while, but this is my first post, so here
goes. You mentioned making an abjad that was for english but was as
flowing as arabic.
messageBody:
I've been listening in for a while, but this is my first post, so here
goes. You mentioned making an abjad that was for english but was as
flowing as arabic. Why not just use arabic then? If you wanted to
simplify it you could use mostly the medial forms and take out the other
three in most cases. They have more consonants than we do anyway, so the
ones where it would be difficult to identify or ones where you didn't
want so many dots you could take out or change. It might also be
advisiable to take out the forms that drop unnecessarily below the line
since that takes up space that dit doesn't need to. I'm not sure if
arabic diacritics would work as they are, but with a little
supplementation they chould do. This has the advantage of already
existing, being as flowing as arabic, and making english somewhat more
accessible to a quite a few people in the world. On the subject of
quickscript, I really have no idea what to do with it, but if somebody
would send me an email (magnet10@...) or refer to somewhere that
talked about which letters connected how, that would go a long way to
making me funcitonal in it.

Colin Grant
